channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Declare Yom Kippur a U.N. Holiday
item.description: Important United Nations events — even, sometimes, meetings related to Israel — have repeatedly been scheduled on major Jewish holidays.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL S. MARIASCHIN and DAVID J. MICHAELS

item.title: Mayor Klaus Wowereit of Berlin Says He Will Step Down
item.description: Mayor Wowereit, who once described Germany’s capital city as “poor but sexy,” said Tuesday that he would leave the post in December after more than 13 years in the job.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Klaus Wowereit, the mayor of Berlin, announced on Tuesday that he will step down in December.

item.title: Open Source: ISIS Conspiracy Theories Include One That It’s an American Plot
item.description: Supporters of Egypt’s military relied on fabricated quotes said to be from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s memoir to bolster claims that the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is part of an American plot.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: 1,400 Children in Rotherham, England, Were Sexually Abused, Report Says
item.description: A report by the local government says that officials over the years had ignored or discounted red flags of the abuse, which dated to 1997.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: American Man Fighting for ISIS Is Killed in Syria
item.description: The 33-year-old man, identified as Douglas McAuthur McCain of San Diego, died in recent days in a battle with a rival rebel group, a senior American official said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Afghan Presidential Candidate Threatens to Withdraw From Election
item.description: Abdullah Abdullah will stop cooperating with an audit of the disputed election results unless his demands are met, a top aide said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Independent Election Commission workers recount ballots in Kabul, on Monday.

item.title: Mumbai Jewish Center Reopens After ’08 Terror Attack
item.description: Rabbis from around the world gathered to reopen the Chabad-Lubavitch center and to remember the six people who were killed there.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabbis reopened Nariman House, a Jewish center attacked in 2008 during a killing spree by Pakistani gunmen, on Tuesday in Mumbai.

item.title: For Yazidis Betrayed by Arab Neighbors, ‘It Will Never Be the Same’
item.description: Yazidis who fled the violence in northern Iraq left with a deep sense of betrayal after Arab neighbors who they thought were friends turned on them, some even joining the militants.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bahia Mamo, a Yazidi living in a refugee camp in northern Iraq, wept over the kidnapping of a relative by ISIS militants.

item.title: New French Cabinet Ousts Prominent Leftists
item.description: A day after infighting led to the collapse of the government, Prime Minister Manuel Valls appointed centrist political allies in a bid to crush an open rebellion in his Socialist Party.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France was expected to appoint a cabinet of centrist political allies on Tuesday.

item.title: Liberian Doctor Treated With an Experimental Drug Dies From Ebola
item.description: Dr. Abraham Borbor, deputy chief medical doctor at Liberia’s largest hospital, received ZMapp — the same drug given to two infected Americans who survived.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: In Thailand’s Surrogacy Industry, Profit and a Moral Quagmire
item.description: Recent scandals have focused scrutiny on the largely unregulated practice of paid surrogacy, prompting a government crackdown.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Giorgio Taraschi for The New York Times
item.media:description: "There’s nothing wrong with surrogacy — you are helping people who can’t have a baby,” said Pakson Thongda, 42, whose daughter twice sold eggs to a fertility clinic for about $1,000 each time.

item.title: AIDS Progress in South Africa Is in Peril
item.description: Though few Americans realize it, South Africa owes much of its success in the fight against AIDS to a single United States program — one that is now moving elsewhere.
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Children in class at a Ndlovu Care Group facility. With aid from the Pepfar program, organizations like Ndlovu and Right to Care have been critical to the reduction of AIDS in South Africa.

item.title: Clouding Talks, Ukraine Says It Captured Russian Troops
item.description: Ukraine released video of what it said were captured Russian soldiers, raising tensions as President Vladimir V. Putin met with his Ukrainian counterpart, Petro O. Poroshenko.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left; Catherine Ashton, the European Union's foreign policy chief, second left; President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, center; and President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, held talks in Minsk, Belarus, about the situation in Ukraine.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Fabled Uighur Princess Coming to Chinese Television as a Cartoon
item.description: Animators in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen are creating a 104-episode animated series loosely based on a historical Qing Dynasty imperial consort, the Fragrant Concubine, who is shrouded in myth.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The central character of "Princess Fragrant," an animated series to be broadcast next year.

item.title: Hamas and Israel Agree to Extended Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: The long-term deal, proposed by Egypt, halts the longest, bloodiest battle either side has experienced in years, but without resolving many of the bigger issues underlying the conflict.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Palestinians inspecting the damage to the Italian Complex after several late night Israeli airstrikes in Gaza City.

item.title: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Are Growing, and Growing More Dangerous, Draft of U.N. Report Says
item.description: The report says that warming has already led to food and climate crises, and that the failure to reduce emissions will lead to worse catastrophes.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:credit: Kadir van Lohuizen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Where ice once capped the Sermeq Avangnardleq glacier in Greenland, vast expanses of the Arctic Ocean are now clear.

item.title: Berlin’s Openly Gay Mayor Says He Will Step Down
item.description: Klaus Wowereit, the mayor of Berlin who once described Germany’s capital city as “poor but sexy,” said Tuesday that he would leave the post in December after more than 13 years in the job.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Klaus Wowereit, the mayor of Berlin, announced on Tuesday that he will step down in December.

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Welsh Strive to Keep Their Language
item.description: Welshness, more than any other national identity in Britain, relies on its linguistic and cultural legacy.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: A road sign in English and Welsh in Cardiff, Wales.

item.title: U.N. Urges Europe to Act on Flood of Migrants
item.description: Record numbers of people are putting their lives in the hands of smugglers and many are dying for their effort.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Workers removed the bodies of migrants that washed onto the shore Monday near Tripoli, Libya.

item.title: Mexican Leader’s Approval Ratings Fall Amid Economic Concerns
item.description: Two-thirds of Mexicans disapprove of the way the President Enrique Peña Nieto is handling the economy, and of the situation in the country, according to a poll by Pew.
item.dc:creator: By MARJORIE CONNELLY

item.title: Brazil Prison Revolt Ends After Deal Is Reached
item.description: The deadly uprising at the penitentiary in Cascavel was halted after the authorities agreed to transfer hundreds of inmates to other prisons.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Liberian Leader Reported to Fire Officials for Defying Ebola Order
item.description: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf had ordered cabinet ministers and senior officials to return home to help confront the outbreak.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Appointment at Chinese Journalism School Highlights Growing Party Role
item.description: There was much uproar after Lin Zhibo, an editor at the Communist Party’s mouthpiece People’s Daily, who once dismissed the scale of the 1958-61 Great Famine, was appointed head of the journalism school at Lanzhou University.
item.dc:creator: By DAMON YI and AMY QIN

item.title: New Palestinian Town in West Bank Awaits Israel’s Approval for Water
item.description: Rawabi, a heralded enterprise in the West Bank, lacks residents more than a year after its first 600 apartments were sold, becoming a cautionary tale about investing in the area.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Gaza, Victim of History
item.description: The Gaza Strip is a far less complex issue than East Jerusalem or the West Bank. So why has it become such a place of misery?
item.dc:creator: By JEAN-PIERRE FILIU
